question: how does research help make nursing practice safe.

key_points.point_content: Research helps identify causes of medical errors and develop models to minimize errors, mechanisms for reporting and corrective action, and methods to reduce paperwork.
Research identifies key aspects of nurses' work environment that impact patient safety and recommends improvements to increase safety.
Research findings and dissemination of successful practices help healthcare organizations improve patient safety continuously.

Research is needed to provide better information on nursing-related errors, safer work processes, patient acuity measurement, safe staffing levels, fatigue compensation, work hours limits, and collaborative care models.
Research provides the foundation for high-quality, evidence-based nursing care.
There isn't a direct flow of knowledge from research into practice, indicating a gap between research and bedside nursing.
Nurses are inquisitive, think critically about their patients’ care, and want to know the best treatments for their patients, making them suited for research.
Research is often perceived as something undertaken by others far removed from the front lines of nursing practice, which affects integration of research into nursing identity.
Nurses who valued research were more likely to use research findings in practice, suggesting a need for a stronger link between nurse clinicians and research development.
Nurses could turn many quality improvement (QI) projects into research, viewing research as a continuum with QI projects along it.

More bedside nurses are likely to engage in research if nursing education is strengthened, time is allocated for research, consultant resources are available, and institutional support is strengthened.
Making research a part of nursing identity and practice will pave the way to evidence-based practice becoming the norm and make nursing practice safer.
Research evidence can inform the delivery of nursing practice in ways that not only improve patient care but also protect nurses’ wellbeing.
Nurses with research skills are equipped for evidence-based practice to ensure better standards for caregiving.

Nurse researchers support and coordinate studies related to a wide range of clinical, community and education issues, and providers use this research to evaluate and improve healthcare for millions of people.
Nursing research is importance as it offers a body of knowledge that goes a long way in the advancement of nursing practice.
The findings from nursing research may influence health policy and consequently lead to improved health outcomes.
It is imperative for professional nurses to have an understanding of research principles as it would help them undertake research or at the very least be better consumers of research.
Nursing research is the road map to professional practice.
Evidence-based practice integrates a systematic search for and critical appraisal of the most relevant evidence, clinical expertise, and patient preferences to improve nursing care.

Historically, nursing care was based on tradition without questioning the evidence or impact on patient outcomes, but now there is greater emphasis on implementing nursing care supported by the best research available.

The steps in applying evidence-based practice include defining the problem, reviewing and evaluating data, designing a practice change based on data, and implementing the change while considering nurse experience and patient preferences.
Nursing research utilization involves transferring research findings to clinical nursing practice to ensure quality and improve patient outcomes.
Nurses conduct research to build a solid base of evidence for stronger practices that benefit patients, families, and inter-professional teams.
Research helps nurses understand and adjust medical equipment and alarms to be appropriate for pediatric patients, reducing undue stress and improving care.
Nurses use research to update and change clinical practices and policies based on new evidence, improving patient safety and care quality.
Nursing research is increasingly collaborative and inter-professional, enriching research outcomes and improving patient care.
Nursing research legitimises nursing as a profession and education has been reformed to reflect a research base, but only a moderate proportion of nurses use research as a basis for practice.
Nurses perceive research positively but face barriers such as lack of access to information and skills in critical appraisal, which hinders the use of research in practice.
Evidence-based nursing aims to bridge the gap between researchers and practitioners to make research more accessible and useful for nursing practice.
Nursing requires different types of evidence including scientific knowledge, social sciences evidence, and experiential knowledge to improve patient care.

Different research designs are needed to answer different nursing questions, including scientific methods for causation and effectiveness, and interpretist approaches for understanding patient experiences.
Nurses must develop skills to critique scientific evidence and design trials to improve nursing, while also valuing naturalistic studies and experiential knowledge.
Nursing research has a tremendous influence on current and future professional nursing practice, thus rendering it an essential component of the educational process.
Evidence-based practice (EBP) is a patient-centered approach founded on independent scientific research, clinical expertise, standardized practice and patient experiences.
Nurse researchers play a vital role in all aspects of health care delivery, from policy development to nurse education to community health best practices.
There is an ongoing need for health care providers to evaluate current best practices and develop new protocols based on their findings.
Nursing research identifies ways to make nurse education more effective.
Nurse research looks at how health care is delivered, and how that influences the cost and quality of the service, as well as the experience of patients and families.
Nurse research seeks to identify the treatment protocols that are most effective for patients across the spectrum.

Nursing research looks at the overall health of patients; it considers disease within the lenses of health promotion, rehabilitation, and restoration, and looks for better ways to provide care and comfort that meet patients’ needs.

Nurse researchers take what medical researchers discover about disease and expand it to investigate the social, emotional, and behavioral aspects to help develop protocols that improve outcomes and overall quality of life.
Nurse research helps identify new practices for nurses, so they can become more effective health care leaders and advocates for both their patients and overall health care improvement.
Research nurses play a key role as patient advocate, ensuring patients’ safety and protection, and that patients are well supported throughout the research study.
Critical thinking skills are essential for all nurses. They are a necessity for the provision of safe, high-quality clinical care.
